faculty.name: Alexandra Kostina
faculty.title: Associate Professor
faculty.education: M.A. Novgorod State University; Ph.D. Gornyi University/Russian State Pedagogical University

courses: Russian 205: The Russian Religious Mind and either Russian 212: Prophets, Princesses, and Revolutionaries or Russian 300: Dostoevsky
Two courses from Russian 301, 302, 309 (All advanced Russian)
Russian 410: Analytical Reading, Russian 486: Senior seminar
Russian 285: Putin’s Russia and the Media and ML280: Introduction into General Linguistics
encouragedActivity: Majors are encouraged to spend at least one semester studying in Russia.
Two of the following: Russian 205: Russian Religious Mind, 212: Prophets, Princesses, and Revolutionaries, 285: Putin’s Russian and the Media, 300: Dostoevsky, 410: Analytical Reading
Substitutions are possible (say, you took a relevant course in IS or History, they can be applied toward your major or minor), which may make it easier to major or minor in Russian Studies.

101-102.title: Elementary Russian
101-102.description: Elementary grammar, reading, and conversation, supplemented by materials on Russian culture.

201-202.title: Intermediate Russian
201-202.description: Intermediate grammar and continued training in conversation and composition, supplemented by materials on contemporary developments in Russian society. Reading of Russian texts of graded difficulty, intermediate writing. Prerequisites: Russian 101-102 or equivalent.

205.title: The Russian Religious Mind
205.description: Examines the distinct world-consciousness of Russian religious tradition and thought, with emphasis on key themes and readings from Orthodox monastics, Russian religious philosophers, and contemporary writers.

209.title: Russian in Russia
209.description: A guided encounter with language and culture in Russia aimed at solidifying vocabulary and grammar previously acquired. Includes significant cultural immersion. Takes place in May-June.

212.title: Prophets, Princesses, and Revolutionaries
212.description: Reading of representative works by major Russian writers of the nineteenth century, exploring their literary merit and contributions to understanding Russian society. All works are read in translation.

215.title: Giants of Russia’s Silver Age
215.description: Study of connections among Vladimir Soloviev, Alexander Blok, and Sergei Rachmaninoff. Examines themes of Russian Orthodox religiosity, beauty, and goodness through their works.

255.title: Catherine the Great and the Enlightenment
255.description: Investigates Italian-Russian cultural connections during Catherine the Great's reign, focusing on music, literature, and architecture. Optional study trip to Italy and Russia.

256.title: Catherine the Great and the Italian-Russian Connection
256.description: Examines musical, literary, and architectural connections between Italy and Russia during Catherine the Great's reign. Study trip to Rome, Milan, and St. Petersburg in May-June.

285.title: Putin's Russia and the Media
285.description: Explores important media sources on contemporary Russia, highlighting underrepresented perspectives in Western narratives. Provides insight into Russian society and geopolitics.

300.title: Dostoevsky
300.description: Examines selected works by Dostoevsky in the context of the Russian novel's rise. Focuses on literary, philosophical, and religious themes.

301-302.title: Advanced Russian
301-302.description: Advanced grammar, with emphasis on conversation and composition skills related to contemporary life in Russia. Prerequisites: Russian 201-202 or equivalent.

309.title: Russian in Russia
309.description: Guided encounter with language and culture in Russia aimed at solidifying vocabulary and grammar. Includes significant cultural immersion. Takes place in May-June.

400.title: Russian Film: Film Theory
400.description: Introduction to ideological and aesthetic forces shaping Soviet/Russian film, with attention to various film theories. Study of major directors and their films.

410.title: Analytical Reading
410.description: Teaches strategies for understanding texts of high literary quality through psycho-poetic and formal analysis.

486.title: Senior Seminar
486.description: Research-based seminar focusing on the Russian Idea. Includes weekly progress reports and presentation of research results.

495-496.title: Honors Tutorial
495-496.description: Individualized tutorial for honors students, involving research and writing of an honors paper.
